titleStmt.title: The young-mans vvish, or, Behold his mind fulfil'd, whom love had almost kil'd, vvith joy reviv'd againe, as heere appeareth plaine: the like to this, ('twixt man and wife) I never heard yet, in all my life. To the tune of, I am in love, and cannot tell with whom.
titleStmt.author: L. P. (Laurence Price), fl. 1625-1680?

titleStmt.title: The young-mans vvish, or, Behold his mind fulfil'd, whom love had almost kil'd, vvith joy reviv'd againe, as heere appeareth plaine: the like to this, ('twixt man and wife) I never heard yet, in all my life. To the tune of, I am in love, and cannot tell with whom.

publicationStmt.publisher: for Iohn Wright, the younger, and are to be sold at his shop at the upper end of the Old-Bayley.,

notesStmt.note: Verse: "VVhat strange affections have my thoughts possest ..."
In two parts, separated for mounting; woodcuts at head of each part.
Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Young-mans Wish, OR,

head.l: Behold his mind fulfil'd, whom Love had almo≈øt kil'd,
VVith joy reviv'd againe, as heere appeareth plaine:
The like to this, ('twixt Man and Wife)
I never heard yet, in all my Life.

div.opener: To the tune of, I am in Love, and cannot tell with whom.

lg.l: VVHat ≈øtrange affections have my thoughts po≈ø≈øe≈øt,
that nothing will nor can my mind content?
Or why ≈øhould love my inward parts mole≈øt,
or time away in patience thus be ≈øpent?
The cau≈øe Ile ≈øhew, but oh my heart will breake;

l.hi: I am in love, but know not how to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: My Humors and my Fancies all are cro≈øt,
my minde ≈øo much di≈øturb'd I cannot ≈øleepe;
By day my wits like tennis Balls are to≈øt,
and every hower in dolefull dumps mo≈øt d√©epe:
I am ca≈øt downe, all plea≈øures I for≈øake,

l.hi: The rea≈øon is, I love and cannot ≈øpeake.

lg.l: Sometimes my Mu≈øe a≈øcendeth up on high,
and climes Parna≈ø≈øus hils for learnings lore;
As ≈øoone againe it in the d√©epe doth lie,
now high, then low; now rich, and ≈øtraightway poore:
Now laugh & ≈ømile, yet ≈øtraight my heart will breake;

l.hi: For ≈øtill I love and know not how to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: I wander up and downe, and yet ≈øtand ≈øtill;
I walke abroad, and yet lie ≈øick in bed:
I live at libertie, and yet my will
is into de≈øolation captive led:
My health I have, yet life doth me for≈øake,

l.hi: Though ≈øtill I love, I know not how to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: I f√©ede, I fea≈øt, I fare on dainty dyet;
I drinke the fre≈øhe≈øt wine, yet ≈øtill am dry:
I take my re≈øt, and yet can have no quiet;
I ≈øtand in water, yet in flames I frye:
I ≈øulphur greatly, yet with cold I ≈øhake:

l.hi: I love in heart, and yet I dare not ≈øpeake.

lg.l: I weare good clothes, and yet I naked goe,
with decent ge≈øture ≈ø√©emely to behold;
I am adorn'd from top unto the toe;
And yet my ≈øhape is loth≈øome double fold:
I have my wits, and yet I doe mi≈øtake,

l.hi: 'Tis all becau≈øe I love, and cannot ≈øpeake.

lg.l: I heare, I ≈ø√©e, I ≈ømell, I ta≈øte, I touch,
and yet am ≈øenceles growne in every thing;
Great want I f√©ele, yet have (me thinks) too much,
each ounce of mirth, a pound of griefe doth bring:
I am inforc'd thus to the world to breake

l.hi: My minde; but to my Love I cannot ≈øpeake.

lg.l: I live in peace, yet hold an inward ≈øtrife,
Cupid that villaine wounded ≈øo my heart;
I ≈øingle am, yet faine would have a Wife,
to ea≈øe me of my dolour, griefe and ≈ømart:
But ≈øhe with whom I gladly would partake,

l.hi: Makes me aba≈øh'd, I know not how to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: O That ≈øome Oratour would be ≈øo kinde,
to plead my cau≈øe, and certifie my love;
My pa≈ø≈øions and di≈øturbances of minde.
to try if ≈øhe will prove my Turtle Dove:
What almes or an≈øwer ≈øhe to me would make,

l.hi: For oh alas, I love, but cannot ≈øpeake.

lg.l: But ≈øince no meanes or way I can invent,
to bring her tidings of my hearts de≈øire;
My time in Wi≈øhes ≈øhall be wholly ≈øpent,
and Phoenix-like Ile wa≈øt my ≈øelfe in fire:
For while I live Ile ≈øorrow for her ≈øake,

l.hi: Becau≈øe I want both Art and heart to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: O that I were ≈øome curious King of Gold,
to weare upon her finger for delight;
That by ≈øome Merchant ≈øo I might be ≈øold
for her owne u≈øe and ≈øervice day and night:
Or would I were a bond-≈ølave for her ≈øake;

l.hi: That feare might force, or Love me cau≈øe to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: Could I but crave to light her to her bed,
it ≈øurely would revive my drooping heart;
Or lay ≈øoft pillowes underneath her head;
till dalliance long had made us loth to part:
So finding ≈øcope, my wi≈øhed mind I'd breake,

l.hi: By ≈øignes, to heare, or touch, if not to ≈øpeake.

lg.l: But O my heart, my wi≈øhes are in vaine,
no hopes have I for this which here I crave;
Nor know I any way her love to gaine;
O would the Fates had dig'd my timeles grave:
Where I might re≈øt ≈øecurely in my Tombe,

l.hi: And not be found untill the day of doome.

lg.l: His Love (at la≈øt) who from a window high
had heard the griefes and ≈øorrowes he indur'd;
Thus comforts him with words immediately,
thy love-≈øicke heart (≈øaid ≈øhe) ≈øhall ≈øoone be cur'd:
Thou ≈øhalt no longer cau≈øe have to complaine;

l.hi: If thou lov'≈øt me, Ile quit thy love againe.

lg.l: Thou wi≈øhed≈øt but my company a time;
now here's my hands for ever and for aye,
In weale or woe I will be wholly thine,
my heart, my hand, my life ≈øhall th√©e obay:
So, la≈øtly; thus their loves were truely tride,

l.hi: He was her Bridegroome, ≈øhe his lovely Bride.

div.p: Imprinted at London for Iohn Wright, the younger, and are to be ≈øold at his Shop at the upper end of the Old-Bayley.
